awd_titl_txt: Exploring New Deposition Processes for Astronomical Coatings
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will improve optical coatings for astronomical mirrors. The primary purpose of astronomical telescopes is to gather as much light as possible for analysis. However, at every reflection, a certain amount of light is absorbed by the mirror surface. Currently, the standard mirror coating is aluminum, with roughly a 10% loss at each surface. Since modern telescopes usually use three or more mirrors, this results in 30% or more of the light being lost. Silver is a significantly better reflector than aluminum, losing only about 3% of the light at each reflection. Silver coated mirrors would result in significant gains in light collection at a fraction of the cost of building a new larger telescope. However, silver is prone to tarnishing and corrosion, so it must be covered by transparent protective layers. Progress towards suitable silver mirror coatings has been made in recent years, but a top protective layer that can hold up to years of use is still lacking. This project will address that missing piece by exploring two new thin film deposition techniques that are expected to extend the lifetimes of silver mirror coatings significantly. While this project is aimed specifically at coatings for telescope mirrors, it has potential use in other areas, such as increasing the efficiency of solar concentrators for energy production.

This project will install specialized equipment for exploring new thin film deposition techniques in an existing vacuum chamber. The first new deposition method is High-power Impulse Magnetron Sputtering (HiPIMS). In conventional sputtering, atoms are knocked off source material by ions (charged atoms), and then land on the surface being coated. HiPIMS modifies this by creating the ions in very short pulses at high power, giving the ions more energy. Consequently, the atoms knocked out are also at higher energy, which helps compact the growing thin film. The second new technique is Filtered Cathodic Arc (FCA) deposition, in which an electric arc going directly into the source material vaporizes the material. The outflowing stream contains particles as well as atoms, so a magnetic field is used bend the stream. This filters out particles and neutral atoms, resulting in a very pure stream of high-energy ionized atoms.  In this project, these two high-energy processes will be used to make specialized materials such as diamond-like carbon and certain nitrides. These materials have the properties that are needed for transparent protective layers. In addition, these techniques can deposit silver at very fast rates, which improves reflectivity. Samples of protected-silver mirror coating will be made, and then placed in a harsh environment to indicate how long they will endure on telescopes.

por.por_cntn:
This project's goal was to determine if diamond-like carbon thin films could enhance the durability of silver-based telescope mirror coatings. Such silver-based coatings would provide about 30% increase in photon gathering, reduce the thermal background in the infrared (where the telescope glows) and both save operating costs and avoid loss of observing time if the coatings can be made to last beyond 3 years. These gains would thus advance infrastructure for ground-based astronomy. The University of California Observatories has been involved in a multi-year study to develop such coatings and have nearly reached the goal, but the existing designs are not yet sufficient robust, likely because the top of the protective coating hydrolyzes over time with exposure to humidity and becomes soft. Diamond-like carbon (DLC) films are resistant to hydrolyzation, are mechanically hard, and have low friction which would help with periodic cleaning and may help reduce dust sticking to the surface which can lead to corrosion. During the research we purchased and installed a Filtered Cathodic Arc (FCA) deposition system in our vacuum chamber. FCA systems are known to produce high-quality DLC films by producing a stream of singly-ionized atoms with high energy at the substrate; all other atoms, ions and particulates are "filtered out" by magnetic fields of sophisticated design. Both the purity of the stream and the energy of the ions help to produce the strong sp3 carbon bonds found in diamond rather than the weaker sp2 bonds found in graphite. A good DLC film will have a majority of sp3 bonds.

We were successful in making DLC films with a large percentage of sp3 bonds. The initial films were not sufficiently transparent for our purposes, however. Experiments showed substrate voltage-biasing increased the energy of the impacting carbon ions and did help increase transparency, but not enough. At the end of the project period, we tried using ion-bombardment with Argon ions in conjunction with the FCA and succeeded in producing highly transparent films. Whether these films will solve the durability problem of our existing protected-silver coatings is still to be determined. We are committed to continuing the research to answer this question, which will still take a few months to determine.  We need to fully characterize the DLC films we are producing, and add them to the existing coating design to produce samples for environmental testing.

During the project period we did have some minor results in other areas; in particular, FCA should produce excellent metallic films such as aluminum. However, we found that the reflectivity of the Al films was not as high as for e-beam or filament/flash deposition, and we speculate that this may be because of incorporated argon at the pressures the FCA requires. We have identified a modification that may improve this. However, we also found the narrow beam of the FCA is more difficult to work with than the more traditional metallic deposition methods.
